setting the table, laying the table

extremely high-grade Japanese meal served all at once (on a table with legs)
low tray of food for guests
setting a place, setting the table
food (on a table; esp. a small Japanese table), dinner, cover (in a restaurant)
cook, chef, person who prepares food
dining table, a dish (type of food)
taking care of everything, no need to do anything
placing a meal in front of one
rudely reaching over one's serving tray to grab food behind it with one's chopsticks
extremely high-grade Japanese meal served all at once (on a table with legs)

k_ele.e: 据え膳食わぬは男の恥

r_ele.r: すえぜんくわぬはおとこのはじ

sense.gloss: rejecting the advances of women is a man's shame, shameful is he who spurns a woman's invitation, not eating the meal set before him is a man's shame
medicinal cooking (based on traditional Chinese medicine)

r_ele.r: うちのかしわでのつかさ

sense.gloss: office in charge of the Emperor's meals (ritsuryō system)
Emperor's meal, meal of a noble
high-quality (of a food or drink), premium
setting the table, laying the table
setting up, getting one's ducks in a row, running interference, setting the stage

sdata.j: すっかりお↑膳立↑↓ぜんだ↓てができている。
これは、すでに↑教科書↑↓きょうかしょ↓に↑書↑↓か↓かれている↑結果↑↓けっか↓が↑得↑↓え↓られるようにお↑膳立↑↓ぜんだ↓てをするというものだった。
sdata.e: This was to arrange things so that I obtained the result already written in the textbooks.

sdata.j: ↑旅館↑↓りょかん↓は、↑上↑↓あ↓げ↑膳据↑↓ぜんす↓え↑膳↑↓ぜん↓がうれしいね。
sdata.e: At a Japanese-style inn, they take care of your every need, so you don't have to lift a finger.

sdata.j: でも、お↑箸↑↓はし↓、↑一↑↓いち↓↑膳↑↓ぜん↓しかないの。どうしよう・・・。
sdata.e: But there's only one pair of chopsticks. What shall we do?

sdata.j: ↑彼女↑↓かのじょ↓は↑膳↑↓ぜん↓の↑上↑↓うえ↓のものを↑酔↑↓よ↓った↑手↑↓て↓つきで↑掴↑↓つか↓み↑散↑↓ち↓らしました。
sdata.e: She threw away everything that was on the small dining table in a drunken hand gesture.

sdata.j: ↑食卓↑↓しょくたく↓を↑膳立↑↓ぜんだ↓てしてください。
↑長良川↑↓ながらがわ↓↑温泉↑↓おんせん↓の「↑信長↑↓のぶなが↓おもてなし↑御膳↑↓ごぜん↓」は、↑戦国↑↓せんごく↓↑時代↑↓じだい↓のおもてなし↑料理↑↓りょうり↓「↑本膳↑↓ほんぜん↓↑料理↑↓りょうり↓」を↑現代↑↓げんだい↓↑風↑↓ふう↓にアレンジしたものです。
sdata.e: Nagaragawa Onsen’s “Nobunaga Hospitality Meal” is a modern style adaptation of a Sengoku period hospitality meal (Honzen-ryōri).
